intro: Campomanesia regeliana, commonly known as the Brazilian cherry or carambola, is a small evergreen tree native to South America. It belongs to the Myrtaceae family and is characterized by its glossy, elliptical leaves and clusters of small, white, fragrant flowers. The plant produces distinctive star-shaped fruits that are yellow-orange when ripe, with a sweet and tangy flavor. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sunlight. Due to its ornamental value and edible fruit, it is widely cultivated in gardens and orchards.
